results.title: Pathways
results.material_description: video, projections, text, audio, bespoke screens, tiered  wooden seating , timber and LED strips
results.brief_description:
A collaboration between artist-filmmaker Jeff Doring and the Ngarinyin Aboriginal Corporation. This spatial installation provides access and insight into the art and culture of the Ngarinyin people. The intention is to record and interpret a broad spectrum of Ngarinyin knowledge and law. The work consists of five discrete and interrelated elements:
1. The Introduction zone: a space consisting of a text, audio, visual introduction to the installation.
2. The Water and Wanjina zone: a corridor with apertures that open on the side to reveal visual works.
3. The Man Blood Law zone: a three screen installation with tiered seating that lies at the end of the Water and Wanjina corridor.
4. The Cave zone: an exhibition space which spatially represents a cave with images projected inside it.
5. The Today zone: a space which provides a contemporary perspective on the exhibition via a web installation.

results.title: Senator Thorpe staunchly opposes fracking in the Beetaloo
results.brief_description: Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.
results.title_for_label: Senator Thorpe staunchly opposes fracking in the Beetaloo
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.

Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.

results.title: Lo-Arna 1981
results.creator_credit: Generation Films, Channel 0\28, Bob Weis and Geoffrey Nottage
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Women of the sun (A)”.
Part Four of the “Women of the Sun” series which presents events that occurred to four different aboriginal women, at different periods in time. This episode is set in 1981 and examines the inner turmoil and insecurity of an 18 year old girl when her adoptive parents tell her she is not of French Polynesian descent, but is the daughter of an Aboriginal woman.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Generation Films, Channel 0\28, Bob Weis and Geoffrey Nottage

results.title: Maydina the shadow 1890's
results.creator_credit: Generation Films, Channel 0\28, Bob Weis and David Stevens
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Women of the sun (A)”.
Part Two of a series which presents events that occurred to four different aboriginal women at different periods in time. This episode examines the life of Maydina and her half-caste daughter on a church mission run by a self-appointed guardian at the turn of the century. Follows her struggle to return to a tribal existence and her efforts to prevent her daughter being taken away from her by the mission guardian.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Generation Films, Channel 0\28, Bob Weis and David Stevens

results.title: Nerida Anderson, 1939
results.creator_credit: Generation Films, Channel 0\28, Bob Weis and Stephen Wallace
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Women of the sun (A)”.
Part Three of a series which presents events that occurred to four different aboriginal women at different periods in time. Set in 1939, this episode examines attempts by Nerida Anderson and her family to improve conditions on the Aboriginal Reserve where they live. Such attempts and displays of independence outrage the manager. He has Nerida and her family tried for treason. Realising a no-win situation, the entire population of the reserve pack their belongings and leave.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Generation Films, Channel 0\28, Bob Weis and Stephen Wallace

results.title: Shadow Play [interactive]
results.brief_description: The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows, which visitors can do at the entrance to The Story of the Moving Image.

constellations_primary.name: Shadow play
constellations_primary.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

results.description:
The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows.

Relive the origins of the moving image by casting your own shadow as it bends, towers and twists to craft imagined worlds, wonderous characters and incredible tales in this interactive experience that unites ancient storytelling techniques with modern technology.
description_for_label:
The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows.

Relive the origins of the moving image by casting your own shadow as it bends, towers and twists to craft imagined worlds, wonderous characters and incredible tales in this interactive experience that unites ancient storytelling techniques with modern technology.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Moving Pictures → 01. Light and Shadow → MI-01-AV01

results.title: Doors Will Open
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Rajani Shrestha
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Rajani Shrestha moved to Melbourne from Nepal in 1992 with her husband and son. Rajani recounts the struggle she faced to find meaningful work in a new country. She tells of her journey which eventually led to her working at AMES Australia.

results.title: To do or not to do.....
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Jock Noble
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Jock Noble, CEO of Diversity@work Australia, talks about the impact having Polio had on his childhood and how that has subsequently shaped his career in helping companies to strengthen through diversity in their workforce.

results.title: My Banquet...
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Chey Scovell
results.brief_description: A digital story made as part of the ‘Diversity @ Work’ Program in association with AMES, Australia Post and SBS. Chey Scovell recounts his childhood growing up as an Australian born in Malaysia and the last four years of schooling spent in Papua New Guinea. He tells of the culture shock he experienced when returning back to Australia.
